0.cdata!: Haiti - Programme dUrgence de Reconstruction des Etablissements Scolaires (PURES) : cadre de politique de reinstallation

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency School Reconstruction
            Program (PURES) of the Government of Haiti constitutes the
            World Bank global response to face the urgent situation
            caused by the tropical tempest Fay and hurricanes Gustav,
            Hanna and Ike (FGHI) of August and September, 2008 which
            caused many damages in the country. The project objective is
            to support the Government of Haiti to (i) restore the access
            to fundamental education in chosen public primary schools
            harmed by the hurricanes of August and September, 2008 and
            (ii) develop, show and disseminate norms and improved
            methods for building of safe schools. PURES comprises two
            components. The first one aimed to restore the offer of
            primary schools and the second will allow to reduce and to
            mitigate the vulnerability of scholastic facilities in
            Haiti. However, the PURES activities could have social
            negative impacts and require the application of
            environmental and social protection operational
            instructions. That is why the wording of this project
            provided for the development of a Resettlement Policy
            Framework (RPF) which is the purpose of this study. The
            Resettlement Policy Framework describes the objectives,
            principles and procedures which frame the means of obtaining
            the lands for infrastructures utilities setting up. The RPF
            clarifies the rules that are applicable to the
            identification of the people who are likely to be involved
            in the PURES activities implementation. There are no long
            term impacts anticipated with the construction or
            rehabilitation of schools. As the sites are already
            identified, the risks to destroy buildings and houses are
            practically nonexistent. Nevertheless, on the bare fields,
            certain activities could have moderate or social negative
            minor impacts, notably on the agrarian lands (destruction of
            culture fields).
